payload.title: Arriving at Heathrow (LHR)
payload.description: Heathrow is London's primary hub. The **Elizabeth Line** has revolutionized the arrival experience, offering a balance of speed and price that beats the old Tube lines.
payload.criticalAlert: As of Feb 25, 2026, the **UK ETA** is strictly mandatory for all visa-exempt nationals (US, Canada, EU, etc.). You will be denied boarding at your departure airport if you do not have this digital authorization.
tips: **Elizabeth Line:** This is the best choice for most. It goes directly to the West End (Bond St) and the City (Farringdon/Liverpool St) without changing at Paddington.
**Heathrow Express:** Only take this if you are in a massive rush and your final destination is Paddington. It is the most expensive 'per mile' train in the UK.
**UK ETA:** Apply at least 3 days before travel via the official 'UK ETA' app. It costs £16 and is linked digitally to your passport.
**Terminal Transfer:** Transfers between T2/T3, T4, and T5 are free via the trains, but you must still tap a contactless card or Oyster (you won't be charged).

payload.title: Pay as You Go (PAYG)
payload.description: London is almost entirely cashless. From the Tube to street performers, 'Tap to Pay' is the universal language.
payload.criticalAlert: Do NOT buy an Oyster Card if you have a contactless bank card or Apple/Google Pay. You'll save the £10 non-refundable card fee and get the same daily fare caps.
tips: **Daily Capping:** TfL automatically stops charging you once you hit the daily cap for the zones you've traveled in. Always use the *same* device/card all day to trigger this.
**Foreign Fees:** Check if your bank charges 'Foreign Transaction Fees.' If they do, an Oyster card might actually be cheaper to avoid 20+ small transaction fees daily.
**Weekly Cap:** If you arrive on a Monday, London's weekly cap (Monday–Sunday) offers the best value for long stays.
**Tipping:** A 12.5% 'Service Charge' is usually added to restaurant bills. You do not need to tip extra unless the service was exceptional.

payload.title: Safety & The 'Phone Snatch'
payload.description: London is safe, but high-value smartphone theft is the city's most frequent petty crime, often involving electric bikes or mopeds.
payload.criticalAlert: Never stand near the edge of the curb with your phone out. 'Bike-by' snatching is extremely common in areas like Soho, Shoreditch, and near major Tube exits.
tips: **Back to the Wall:** If you need to check a map, stop, put your back against a building wall, and keep both hands on the phone.
**Unlicensed Minicabs:** Never get into a car that 'looks' like a taxi but isn't a Black Cab or a booked Uber/Bolt. Only Black Cabs can be hailed on the street.
**Pedestrian Safety:** Look BOTH ways. Visitors frequently look the wrong way for oncoming traffic. Look for the 'Look Right' or 'Look Left' markings on the pavement.
